entry.title: 梅里克·加兰 (Merrick Garland) 关于针对苹果所谓垄断诉讼的言论
entry.content:
司法部长梅里克·加兰：

当 iPhone 用户将信用卡或借记卡放入 Apple Wallet 时，Apple 会将自己插入到一个本来可以直接发生在用户和发卡机构之间的流程中。这给苹果用户的隐私和安全带来了额外的潜在故障点。

Apple Pay 通过电子钱包混淆了您的实际信用卡号码， 零售商利用这些号码来跟踪客户是臭名昭著的。它比使用信用卡本身更加私密。我非常怀疑如果允许 NFC 触碰支付，任何银行或信用卡发卡机构都会自己这样做。

这只是苹果为了维持其垄断地位而愿意降低 iPhone 的安全性和私密性的一种方式。最高法院将垄断权定义为“控制价格或排除竞争的权力”。

正如我们在投诉中所述，苹果在智能手机市场拥有这种力量。

当 iPhone 在美国拥有 55% 左右的市场份额时，将 iPhone 定义为垄断显然是司法部需要证明的第一件事。当美国司法部在 20 世纪 90 年代末起诉微软时，微软占据了 PC 操作系统市场 90% 以上的市场份额。美国司法部试图通过定义“高性能智能手机”市场来绕开苹果公司仅占 55% 份额这一令人不安的事实。我真的不明白苹果对其他公司生产的手机的价格有什么影响力。

现在，拥有垄断权力本身并不违反反垄断法。但当一家公司获得或维持垄断权力时——不是因为它拥有卓越的产品或卓越的商业头脑——而是通过参与排他性行为，就会出现这种情况。正如我们在投诉中所述，苹果公司之所以能保持其权力，并不是因为它的优越性，而是因为它的非法排他行为。

完全倒退了。正是卓越性造就了 iPhone：卓越的硬件、卓越的软件、卓越的集成。甚至卓越的零售体验。

entry.title: 美国司法部起诉苹果公司，指控其非法滥用 iPhone 垄断地位
entry.content:
大卫·麦凯布和特里普·米克尔为《纽约时报》报道：

周四提起的诉讼重点关注政府称苹果用来巩固其主导地位的一系列做法。

政府表示，该公司“破坏”了 iPhone 用户与其他类型智能手机（例如运行 Android 操作系统的智能手机）用户发送消息的能力。诉讼称，这种分歧——以显示 Android 用户信息的绿色气泡为代表——发出了一个信号：其他智能手机的质量低于 iPhone。

当然，SMS是一个比 iMessage 质量低得多的平台。在尚未阅读实际诉讼之前，我很好奇他们认为苹果应该在这方面采取什么不同的做法。 Apple 是否有义务为其他平台提供 iMessage 客户端？免费？

政府认为，苹果公司也同样让 iPhone 难以与自家 Apple Watch 以外的智能手表配合使用。一旦 iPhone 用户拥有了 Apple Watch，他们放弃手机的成本就会变得更高。

简而言之，苹果外设和苹果设备专用的苹果软件就是苹果所做的事情以及让他们的产品受欢迎的原因。这个总结充满了技术天真的味道。例如，美国司法部声称，Apple Watch 和 iPhone 的配合比第三方手表与 iPhone 配合得更好，这并不是因为特定的集成，而是因为苹果将第三方拒之门外。与 Tile 追踪器与 AirTags 相同。唯一的选择是允许第三方在 iOS 上安装系统软件扩展，就像在 Mac 或 PC 上一样。

观看 DOJ 新闻发布会（准备好的声明的文字记录，包括司法部长 Merrick Garland 的文字记录，请参见此处），DOJ 的论点中存在着强烈的暗流，即 iPhone 用户正在集体尝试转向 Android，但发现它太困难且成本太高。这不是基于现实。从 2007 年开始，我见过的每一次客户满意度调查都显示 iPhone 用户非常满意。它不仅是历史上最成功的消费电子产品（也许是产品，一个时期），而且可以说是最受欢迎的。

entry.title: BB编辑15
entry.content:
BBEdit 15.0.2 刚刚发布，这提醒我我从未链接到 BBEdit 15。在许多新功能中，对我来说最有趣和有用的是：

有一种新的文档类型“ChatGPT 工作表”。与其他文档类型一样，它是从“文件”→“新建”创建的，并提供了与 ChatGPT 进行对话交换的界面。为了使用此功能，您需要一个 ChatGPT 帐户和一个 API 密钥。 [...]

ChatGPT 工作表的工作方式与 shell 工作表类似：输入内容，然后按 Enter 键将其发送到 ChatGPT。 （您还可以使用“发送命令”键盘等效项，如 BBEdit 的“菜单和快捷方式”首选项的“工作表”部分中设置的那样。此命令的默认设置是 Control-Return。）一段时间后，您将接收 BBEdit 将插入到文档窗口中的响应。

如果您希望在响应到达之前取消请求，可以使用 Command-period 或 Control-C 来执行此操作。

只要工作表的语言设置为“Markdown”，ChatGPT 的响应就会自动引用。如果更改工作表的语言，则不会发生此引用。

（由于工作表是 Markdown，您可以在工作表上使用“在 BBEdit 中预览”来可视化它。）

由于聊天在很大程度上取决于历史记录，因此工作表会保存您的提示和服务器的响应。因此，即使您从文本区域删除了以前的提示和响应，文档大小也会随着时间的推移而增长，并且上下文会被保留。

一般来说，BBEdit ChatGPT 工作表是我最喜欢的 ChatGPT 界面，但在使用 ChatGPT 提供编程建议时它们尤其出色。在文本编辑器中以自由格式进行聊天非常方便。

其他主要新功能包括小地图调色板、可定制备忘单以及对“项目”的重大改进。 BBEdit 仍然是我最喜欢的应用程序。新许可证 60 美元，从旧版本升级 30 美元，或者从 Mac App Store每月 4 美元或每年 40 美元。

另请参阅： Michael Tsai和Jason Snell 。

entry.title: 天气预报的准确性不断提高
entry.content:
Hannah Ritchie 在《我们的数据世界》中撰文：

直到 1859 年，英国气象局（Met Office）才发布了第一份航运天气预报。两年后，它首次公开天气预报。虽然气象测量随着时间的推移而不断改进，但随着计算机数值模型的使用，预测发生了巨大的变化。直到一个世纪后的 20 世纪 60 年代，这种情况才开始。

从那时起，预测有了很大改善。我们可以通过一系列测量和不同国家气象组织看到这一点。英国气象局表示，其四天预报现在与 30 年前的一日预报一样准确。

当我还是个孩子的时候，有一个笑话说天气预报总是错的。我不记得上次听到有人开玩笑说天气预报没用是什么时候了。过去 40 年来，7 天的预测已经从抛硬币变成了“高度准确”。 （通过科特克。）

entry.title: 路透社：“欧盟维斯塔格对苹果、元费用、贬低竞争对手产品发出警告”
entry.content:
Foo Yun Chee 在接受欧盟委员兼著名用户体验设计师玛格丽特·维斯塔格 (Margarethe Vestager) 的独家专访后，再次为路透社报道：

新的收费结构包括每个用户帐户每年 50 欧分的核心技术费，即使主要应用程序开发商不使用苹果的任何支付服务，也必须支付该费用，这引发了 Fortnite 创建者 Epic Games 等竞争对手的批评。

维斯塔格表示，新的收费标准引起了她的注意。

“有些事情我们非常感兴趣，例如，新的苹果费用结构实际上是否不会以任何方式吸引人们使用 DMA 的好处。这类事情就是我们将要调查的，”她在接受路透社采访时表示。

已经有几个市场宣布计划开业： AltStore 、 Setapp 、 Mobivention ，当然还有 Epic 的游戏商店，仅举四例。因此，CTF 显然并没有使其“对利用 DMA 的好处没有任何吸引力”。但这是否是维斯塔格的代码，我不知道“我们将宣布 CTF 不合规，不是因为它违反了 DMA 条款，而只是因为我们不喜欢它”。

从昨天关于苹果 DMA 合规计划研讨会的记录来看，EC 的开场白包括这样一句话：“原因是我们希望实现 DMA 精神的合规，而不仅仅是字面上的合规。”

美国的法治不是这样运作的

维斯塔格对 Meta 的新收费表示保留。该公司周二早些时候表示，已提议将 Facebook 和 Instagram 的月订阅费从 9.99 欧元削减近一半至 5.99 欧元，但奥地利隐私活动人士马克斯·施雷姆斯 (Max Schrems) 表示，问题不在于费用水平。

“我认为有很多不同的方式可以通过您提供的服务获利。因为一件事是基于消费数据的非常有针对性的广告。展示广告的另一种方式是使其与上下文相关，”她说。 “因此，我认为继续与 Meta 进行对话非常重要，我们最终还将评估下一步的推动措施是什么，以便他们遵守 DMA。”

如果欧盟委员会想禁止定向广告，他们应该通过一项禁止定向广告的法律。但他们没有。有针对性的广告在欧盟是合法的； Meta 只需为用户提供合理的选择退出即可。维斯塔格似乎在暗示，唯一可以接受的选择退出——“精神”方面——是非定向广告，与 Meta 利润丰厚的定向广告相比，这种广告只产生几分钱。这是欧盟委员会向世界各地的企业发出的重要信息。

维斯塔格还警告公司不要通过贬低竞争对手来阻止用户转向竞争对手，称这种行为可能会引发调查。苹果表示，它的一些变化可能会让用户面临安全风险。

“我认为说这些服务使用不安全是不明智的，因为这与 DMA 无关。 DMA 的目的是为其他服务提供商打开市场来联系你，而你的操作系统的服务提供商将如何确保其安全，这些都由他们来决定。”

因此，侧载应用程序是否危险，或者第三方浏览器引擎是否可能对电池寿命产生不利影响，都无关紧要——如果这些建议会阻止用户更换，那么苹果就无法向客户提出诚实的建议。尽管许多（如果不是大多数）人们选择苹果产品的全部原因是他们信任苹果。显然，欧盟不是美国，但声称一家公司向客户提供真相是非法的，这在我美国人的耳朵里听起来是不是完全错误呢？ （这正是我一直如此坚决反对苹果自己在应用商店中制定反转向规则的原因。）

entry.title: Meta 提议降低欧盟 Facebook 和 Instagram 的无广告订阅费，但批评者希望完全不收取任何费用
entry.content:
Foo Yun Chee 在 EC DMA 合规研讨会第二天为路透社报道：

Meta Platforms 的一位高级高管周二表示，Meta Platforms 已提出将 Facebook 和 Instagram 的每月订阅费从 9.99 欧元减半至 5.99 欧元，此举旨在解决隐私和反垄断监管机构的担忧。此次降价是在隐私活动人士和消费者团体对 Meta 在欧洲的无广告订阅服务提出越来越多的批评之后进行的，批评者称该服务要求用户付费以确保其隐私。 Meta 于 11 月推出了这项服务，以遵守《数字市场法案》(DMA)，该法案限制了其在未经用户同意的情况下为用户提供个性化广告的能力，从而损害了其主要收入来源。 [...]

奥地利隐私活动人士马克斯·施雷姆斯表示，问题与费用无关。

“我们从所有研究中得知，即使费用仅为 1.99 欧元或更少，也会导致同意率从 3-10% 真正想要广告的人转变为 99.9% 仍然点击“是”的人。 GDPR 要求必须‘自由’给予同意，”他指的是欧盟隐私立法。

“事实上，这与钱的多少无关——而是与‘付钱或没问题’的整体态度有关。 “付费或同意”的全部目的是让用户点击“同意”，即使这不是他们自由和真实的选择。我们认为，仅仅改变金额并不能使这种做法合法。”

考虑按地区划分的Meta 每季度每用户平均收入 (ARPU) 。对于美国和加拿大，每个用户每季度的费用约为 50-60 美元，或者每年超过 200 美元。在经济停滞不前的欧洲，这一数字约为每季度 20 美元，并且还在不断上升。 （这一数字可能因欧洲较富裕的非欧盟国家（尤其是英国）而被夸大，但 Meta 并未按国家/地区细分 ARPU。）因此，每月 10 欧元是一个合理的交易，尤其是在推断 Meta 的 ARPU 趋势线时。每月 6 欧元确实很划算——选择付费的用户将产生略低于平均水平的收入，但可以获得无广告体验。 （很抱歉在这里混淆了欧元和美元，但它们目前足够接近——1美元 ≈ 0.92 欧元——可以互换对待以进行大致比较。）

但施雷姆斯的论点似乎是，应该要求 Meta 完全免费提供 Instagram 和 Facebook 的无跟踪版本。 Meta 可以向这些用户展示广告，但不是那种真正能赚钱的广告。 “为什么不能通过非个性化广告而不收取订阅费来维持业务？”根据 Kay Jebelli 对研讨会的现场报道，这是今天提出的一个实际问题。下一步：地狱里有免费冰水吗？

隐私原教旨主义者似乎感到不安，因为当在带有个性化广告的免费服务（以及跟踪以实现个性化）和支付公平的服务费用之间进行选择时，绝大多数人选择了个性化广告。

entry.title: “冗长的备忘录和官样文章语言”
entry.content:
Smaller War Plants Corporation 董事长兼总经理 Maury Maverick 在 1944 年的全公司备忘录中写道：

简短并使用简单的英语。

备忘录应尽可能简短、清晰。发送“视线潜艇——沉没萨姆”电报的海军军官讲述了整个故事。

将真正的主题（要点）甚至结论放在一页的开头段落和整个故事中。时期！如果需要冗长的解释、统计问题等，请使用附件。

远离官样文章。这只会让人们犯难。看在上帝的份上，请简短地说出您正在谈论的内容。让我们停止“指向上”的计划，停止“最终确定”“源于”地区、地区或华盛顿“级别”的合同。没有“级别”——地方政府的级别与华盛顿政府一样高。不再有模式、效果、动力。任何使用“激活”或“实施”一词的人都会被枪杀。

80 年前的建议今天仍然有效。另外：这是gobbledygook的第一个已知用法，这是一个神话般的词，没有真正的同义词。 （感谢 DF 读者 David Wooten 提供的链接。）

（另外：谁的名字更酷？莫里·马弗里克（Maury Maverick）还是小型战争植物公司（Smaller War Plants Corporation）？）

entry.title: [赞助] WorkOS
欧盟委员会举办“Apple DMA 合规研讨会”
entry.content:
对于苹果 DMA 合规计划的批评者来说，这是一个向苹果代表提出问题的机会。有 9 小时研讨会的视频，但它被密码锁定（在此处插入有关 EC 支持开放性的笑话）。我无法想象坐着经历这一切，即使是在 2 倍的速度下。幸运的是，Kay Jebelli 全程关注并在 Twitter/X 上的帖子中做了大量笔记：

有趣的细节：欧盟委员会告诉苹果，他们不允许对应用程序进行公证以保护用户。因此，“政府当局必须站出来保护”应用程序开发人员和用户免受这些第三方应用程序的风险。

换句话说，欧盟委员会对苹果公司对在应用程序商店之外分发的应用程序进行任何审查存在疑问。 EC 将负责确保恶意软件、网络钓鱼、诈骗、克隆、IP 盗用和盗版应用程序无法通过。这也意味着在应用程序商店之外分发的应用程序将能够使用私有 API。有人可能会说，苹果在 DMA 合规计划中所谓的“公证”实际上只是一种不太广泛的应用程序审查形式，但如果没有这一步，苹果根本无法对商店外分发的软件进行监督。这似乎正是 EC 所说的 DMA 要求。我认为这不会顺利。

[ 3 月 20 日更新： Jebelli 在后续报道中说道：“纵观已经发布的其他一些内容，我可能听错了，重点是公证并不能解决替代分发的所有风险，并且政府必须加强应对这些其他风险（不是因为完全取消公证）。”因此，苹果公证和检查所有应用程序的计划似乎仍然存在。]

在 CTF 的再次推动下，Apple 重申其完全符合 DMA。它不会针对互操作性收取额外费用，而是对其之前通过其原始模式货币化的技术进行补偿（有效地收取数字应用程序销售费用）。

我们从今天的研讨会中得知，(a) 苹果已经在其 DMA 合规计划的各个方面受到了 EC 的具体抵制； (b) 苹果仍然认为 CTF 在 DMA 条款下完全有效。对我来说，这说明 CTF 将会飞翔。 DMA 不允许整个 CTF 的想法是 DMA 不允许公司通过对其自己的平台和 IP 的访问来货币化的论点。欧共体的粉丝听到这个消息可能会感到惊讶，但欧共体是一个资本主义机构。我真的不认为他们想向世界传达欧盟将剥夺公司自己平台的信息。正如 Jebelli 在他的帖子的旁白中写道：

如果您退后一步，您会发现在其他行业中，整个监管框架会突然出现，以解决不同企业之间关于“为什么我不能以零成本免费访问此基础设施？”的问题，这是非常令人难以置信的。 ”

欧盟的爱哭鬼 Spotify 已经从欧盟的保护球拍中得到了很多，包括苹果 DMA 合规计划中的大量巨额让步。不过，在任何情况下都不向苹果支付任何费用是他们所能接受的。

★

entry.title: 轻松调试 Voyager 1
entry.content:
丹尼斯·希尔 (Denise Hill) 在 NASA 的太阳斑博客上写道：

自 2023 年 11 月以来，NASA 的航行者 1 号航天器一直向地球发送稳定的无线电信号，但该信号不包含可用数据。该问题的根源似乎在于三台机载计算机之一，即飞行数据子系统 (FDS)，该子系统负责在遥测调制单元将科学和工程数据发送到地球之前对其进行打包。

3 月 3 日，Voyager 任务团队发现 FDS 的一个部分的活动与计算机无法读取的数据流的其余部分不同。当 FDS 正常工作时，新信号仍然不是航行者 1 号使用的格式，因此团队最初不确定如何处理它。但该机构深空网络的一名工程师能够解码新信号，并发现它包含整个 FDS 内存的读数，该网络负责与航行者号和其他前往月球及其他地方的航天器进行通信。 [...]

由于航行者一号距离地球超过 150 亿英里（240 亿公里），无线电信号需要 22.5 小时才能到达航天器，探测器的响应还需要 22.5 小时才能到达地面天线。因此，团队在 3 月 3 日收到了命令结果。3 月 7 日，工程师开始解码数据，3 月 10 日，他们确定其中包含内存读数。

提醒我永远不要抱怨任何我必须再次调试的事情。

★

entry.summary: 我对苹果这一年的评论（诚然是迟来的）。
entry.content:
上个月 Jason Snell 发布了2023 年年度六色苹果报告卡。正如我过去所做的那样——2022 年、 2021 年、 2020 年、 2019 年、 2018 年——我在这里发布我的完整评论和成绩。我今年出版的时间很晚，因为我上个月忘记了。在斯内尔的成绩单上，选民对每个类别给出的分数从 5 到 1 不等；我已将这些转换为字母等级，A 到 E。

麦克：A

到今年年底，该系列中的每台 Mac（除了一台）都可以说处于该型号有史以来最好的状态。 （剧透：Mac Pro 是个例外。）

当 Apple Silicon 在 2020 年底首次亮相时，苹果首先推出了消费级型号，采用常规 M1 芯片，随后于次年推出 M1 Pro/Max/Ultra 芯片。 M2 一代重复了这种模式。但在 2023 年底，苹果推出了 M3 代苹果芯片，首先是 14 英寸和 16 英寸 MacBook Pro（配备 M3 Pro/Max 芯片），以及配备普通 M3 的较小 14 英寸 MacBook Pro。 MacBook Pros 首先配备新一代芯片比 MacBook Air 更有意义。这些是有史以来最好的 MacBook Pro。

24 英寸 iMac 跳过了 M2 一代，但更新了 M3，同时 Apple 也尽可能明确地表示，他们没有计划使用 Apple 芯片制造 27 英寸 iMac。我对此表示同意 - 我认为 Studio Display 与 Mac Mini 是更好的解决方案。那些怀念英特尔时代 iMac Pro 的人最好选择 Studio Display 和 Mac Studio。

Mac Pro 是该系列中唯一令人不满意的一款。它终于来到了 Apple 芯片上（万岁），但就规格而言，它几乎是一个具有高级 I/O 选项的 Mac Studio（嘘）。如果您的工作需要高端 I/O，那就太好了。但如果没有，除了价格更高和占用办公桌上或办公桌下更多空间之外，很难看出 Mac Pro 提供了 Mac Studio 所没有的任何功能。尽管第一款 Apple 硅 Mac Pro 令人失望，但我认为总体来说这是个好消息，因为这表明苹果仍然希望 Mac Pro 出现在其产品阵容中。在未来一两年的某个时候，我预计苹果将推出一款规格领先于 Mac Studio 的 Mac Pro。显然，苹果芯片还没有出现。

MacOS 13 Ventura 和 14 Sonoma 都是不错的版本。可靠且（大部分）熟悉。

iPhone：A

新款 iPhone 15 系列非常棒，尤其是 15 Pro 型号，苹果将其从重型抛光不锈钢改为轻质拉丝钛金属。重量大幅减轻，而且钛金属的手感更加舒适。

iOS 17（你能相信现在已经到了 17 了吗？）给人的感觉就是：一个稳定成熟的操作系统。 Apple 的 iOS 经历了两次重大转变：iOS 7 的 UI 彻底重新设计（你能相信那是 10 年前的事了吗？），以及 iPhone X 的全屏、不再有 Home 键的系统重新设计。从那时起，没有什么重大改变，似乎也没有什么需要改变。总体而言，从 Lightning 到 USB-C 的转换并没有什么大的争议，并且启用了新功能，例如将 ProRes 视频直接录制到连接的 SSD 上。

iPad：C

由于今年没有新的iPad硬件，很难给它高分，所以它是绅士C。更糟糕的是，现有的阵容相当混乱。 iPados仍然很好，但是对我来说，iPados似乎仍然像是无人的土地平台：在Mac的生产力下远没有能力的生产力；远不如iPhone那样便携。明年最好为iPad阵容带来清晰度和一些“哇”。我很想看到一个完全重新考虑的魔术键盘 - 也许是与iPad一样，与Vision Pro一起使用的组合键盘/触控板？

观看：B /可穿戴设备（包括手表）：B

Series 9型号看起来与第8系列没有什么不同，而Ultra 2看起来与Ultra 1没有什么不同，但是内部，新的S9 SIP芯片可显着地明显更好的电池寿命 - 这实际上是一个平台唯一的弱点。

WatchOS 10是有史以来最大的重新思考。更丰富多彩，更多的“手腕上的计算机”，我认为小部件在Apple Watch上通常比应用程序更有用。

AirPods Pro 2只是很棒的，而新的自适应噪声控制模式对于我的日常使用而言是惊人的。

Apple TV：B

今年硬件方面没有新闻，但这并不需要。 TVO的重大变化是将iTunes电影和电视店移至电视应用程序。总的来说，这对我来说是一次清洗，但是只要我实际上只买或租用电影，我的电视表演就会通过流媒体应用程序，这对我来说有点烦人。但是，电视应用程序中的“商店”选项卡在主屏幕上为一个流行的电视节目提供了突出的位置。我只想看电影。

不过，今年TVO的最佳变化是，遥控器上的圆形上/向下/向下/左/右车轮现在都可以使用：您可以像在Yore的iPod上使用滚轮。不知道为什么它一直没有这样做，但是我敢肯定，现在它很高兴。

服务：b

电视+上有很多精彩的节目和电影。缓慢的马，筒仓，劫机，全人类和花月的杀手都是杰出的。

iCloud保持安全，快速和可靠。跨设备如此多的无缝连续性（包括通过连续性品牌的特征）。

但是，我将重复这几年以来的重复：苹果仍然在Free Tier中仅提供5 GB的存储空间，这真是令人沮丧，并且自从Forever Forever带来了付费层的存储分配不变。我想知道那里有多少千亿iPhone用户没有设备备份，因为他们只有一个带有5 GB的iCloud帐户？ Apple One Bundle是一笔不错的选择，但是免费的iCloud Tier应该对备份现代iPhone确实有用。

HomeKit/Home：C

我将重复去年的台词：大局，这整个事情仍然感觉像是一定要变得良好的“明年”。 2023年不是那年（再次）。

硬件可靠性：

在这一类别中，没有新闻是个好消息。

软件质量：b

我会简短：我对Apple软件设计方向的方面始终存在（或者在某些方面已经存在了多年），但他们的软件可靠性对我来说非常好。

开发人员关系：C

连续第三年提出相同的评论：对App Store政策的不满。 App Store审查过程的挫败感似乎未得到改善。苹果的目标应该是使开发人员关系变得如此好，以至于开发人员希望专门为苹果平台创建软件。相反的情况正在发生。

社会和社会影响：

另一个重复的评论，但在这方面又是一个好年份：气候/碳是像Apple这样的公司可以并且应该最大的社会领域，而我很难想到他们可以做更多的事情，实际上。 2023年看到了几种完全中性碳中性的Apple Watch配置。

我们在其他社会问题上生活在敏感的时期，苹果似乎非常巧妙，诚实地管理。

;

entry.summary: 在电视应用程序中切换封闭标题的两个快捷方式，以支持可访问性功能。
entry.content:
我知道，每当他们看电视时，即使是可以轻松理解对话框的节目和电影，只要他们在看电视时才启用关闭字幕，这是一种趋势。不过，我做不到，因为如果我不需要的话，我发现字幕非常分散。

但是，在过去一周的Netflix上观看了上面的绅士时，我发现自己经常在上面放置字幕，因为我无法理解许多角色所说的Cockney口音。因此，当将开始使用讲Cockney角色的场景时，我会在Apple TV遥控器上刷新，然后在Netflix应用中切换屏幕上的“ CC”按钮。当场景结束时，重复。我只是尝试留下字幕，但是当我知道在说什么时，我确实发现它令人难以置信。这使我认为，与手动刷卡和单击Apple TV Remote TouchPad相比，必须有一种更好的切换字幕方法。

原来有两种更好的方法：

  1. 如果您在iPhone上使用Control Center Apple TV遥控器，则有一个专用的“ CC”按钮。

  2. 在TVOS中，转到设置→可访问性→可访问性快捷方式，然后将其设置为“封闭字幕”。现在，您只需单击遥控器上的菜单/后部按钮即可切换字幕。 （在较旧的Apple电视遥控器上，该按钮标记为“菜单”；在新遥控器上，它标有“ <”。）

但这是挂钩：Netflix的TVOS应用程序不支持这两种方式切换字幕。 Netflix仅支持其自定义视频播放器中的屏幕字幕切换。我明白了为什么Netflix和其他流媒体应用程序想使用自己的自定义视频播放器，但是App Store评论应要求其支持诸如此类的可访问性功能。

您还可以使用遥控器上的Siri切换字幕：“打开字幕”或“关闭字幕”（或使用“字幕”一词）。最酷的功能是：“他/她/他们刚刚说了什么？”，它倒带15秒并暂时打开字幕。在所有主要TVOS流媒体应用程序（包括Netflix）中似乎都起作用的所有酷功能，但没有任何借口不支持三重单击可访问性快捷方式和控制中心遥控器中的CC按钮。

POSTSCRIPT： Ben Markowitz在十几个流行的TVOS应用程序中尝试了字幕可访问性快捷方式。仅在Paramount+和ESPN中起作用。太可怕了。

entry.summary: 我怀疑苹果从一开始就开始从网上下载开始 - 他们知道EC *可能需要它的要求 - 因此，他们1月25日通过他们希望飞行的合规计划开放了自己的手随着他们获得反馈的反馈，既可以从开发人员那里获得反馈，又是他们可能拥有的任何EC频道。
entry.content:
苹果开发人员新闻，昨天：

同意欧盟应用程序的替代术语附录的开发人员在欧盟中为其应用程序提供了新的选项：

  • 替代应用市场。市场可以选择仅来自市场开发商的应用程序目录。

  • 链接到购买。指示用户在外部网页上完成数字商品或服务的交易时，开发人员可以选择如何设计促销，折扣和其他交易。现已选择用于关键购买和促销用例的Apple提供的设计模板现已可选。

这两个调整跟随一周前的另外三个调整。上面的第一个新公司意味着像Adobe或Microsoft这样的公司可以为自己的应用程序提供一个市场。第二个是一个更大的让步 - 有效地消除了强制性苹果设计的恐慌片，以将其链接到网络。听起来第二次真正消除了选择新欧盟规则的开发人员的反向发展规定。

然后，繁荣，大个子：

Web Distribution将于今年春季晚些时候提供软件更新，将使授权的开发人员直接从开发人员拥有的网站向欧盟用户分发其iOS应用程序。 Apple将为授权的开发人员访问API，以促进其应用程序从Web分发，与系统功能集成，备份并恢复用户的应用程序等等。有关详细信息，请访问Ready准备在欧盟进行Web发行。

因此，直接下载 - 从开发人员自己的网站上进行的单个应用侧载 - 现在是一个选择。魔鬼是这些细节：

为了有资格获得Web分发，您必须：[...]

  • 在苹果开发人员计划中担任良好的成员，已连续两年或更长时间，并且在上一年的日历年中，在欧盟的iOS上拥有超过一百万个以上的年度安装。

  • 同意，除其他外

    • 仅提供开发人员帐户的应用程序。

    • 响应Apple的通信有关通过Web分发分发的应用程序的通信，尤其是在任何欺诈，恶意或非法行为上，或Apple认为会影响用户的安全性，安全性或隐私的其他任何东西。

    • 发布透明的数据收集策略，并为用户控制其数据的收集和使用方式。

    • 遵循您操作的司法管辖区的适用法律（例如，《数字服务法》，《一般数据保护法规》和消费者保护法）。

    • 负责处理政府和其他要求删除应用程序列表的要求。

在欧盟拥有超过100万个年度安装的应用程序的资格要求是一个高障碍。显然，目的是将Web分布限制在表面上值得信赖的开发人员身上。但这有点像Catch-22：整个功能是定义上的在应用商店或应用程序市场中流行的应用程序。

如果这种变化是通过后通道反馈的欧共体要求的，那么EC似乎只关注大型开发人员。对我来说，这种变化（这是一个巨大的变化）是从与EC进行的后渠道通信之外的任何地方都没有意义的。就在六周前，苹果公司对其原始合规计划的介绍竭尽。如果苹果公司想从开发人员自己的网站上直接下载单个应用程序，那么他们将从一开始就将其包括在内。但是，鉴于该功能将在“今年春天晚些时候”（在WWDC之前）提供，他们似乎已经在努力，为EC公开或私人地说，DMA需要它。但是，如果苹果想允许Web发行，那将是最初公告的一部分。

到目前为止，苹果公司对其合规计划的几乎所有变化都只是政策变化。市场提供商不一定需要获得一百万美元的备用信用证。选择新的欧盟规则的开发人员现在可以改变主意，然后返回原始业务条款。拥有多个开发人员帐户的公司可以按帐户的基础（而不是全或无人）选择新规则。公司可以仅针对自己的应用创建市场。所有只是政策变化。所有这些政策变化很可能是开发人员直接反馈的结果。很容易想象，苹果从未考虑过拥有多个开发人员帐户的公司可能只想将其中一些帐户转移到新的业务条款上。我不明白为什么苹果会谴责这些更改中的任何一个，甚至是IOTA。可以将它们提交给“当然，我们只是没有想到这一点。 ”

该链接屏幕现在可能包含促销和定价信息，并且不需要关注Apple的模板 - 这也是政策的变化，但我怀疑Apple确实感到诚挚。显然，这是开发人员想要的。您是否想要一个非常纯净的，完全无品牌的屏幕，它强调了苹果生态系统的安全范围的任何内容？还是您想以自己的重点以自己的风格来设计自己的屏幕？对我来说，这是根据EC的要求进行的变化。

但是随后是Web分布 - 这既是重大的政策变化，又是主要的技术。 （对于Web下载的应用程序，软件更新将如何工作？为此，软件更新将如何适用于市场应用程序本身？Foobar Marketplace应用程序可以以某种方式自行更新？如果没有运行背景过程，这似乎是不可能的。）正如我之前指出的那样，苹果在六个星期前将直接的网络下载描述为一个坏主意。

我对此没有小的小鸟信息，但是只有在他们有理由相信ec在DMA下必须强制性的情况下，就可以改变这个问题的苹果政策才有意义。只有至少一百万个欧盟下载应用程序的长期开发人员才能与DMA完全兼容。 DMA中对小型或独立开发人员的利益根本没有什么。

随着史蒂文·辛诺夫斯基（Steven Sinofsky）在对DMA的分析中详细说明，DMA也希望吃蛋糕并食用。它要求Apple既要开放iOS，以使iOS采用其他软件分发方法，并保持iOS尽可能安全。允许直接下载，但仅来自已经成功的开发人员，与此相符。我怀疑苹果已经准备好从一开始就开始下载了 - 他们知道EC可能会要求它 - 因此，他们1月25日通过他们希望飞行的合规计划开放了自己的手随着他们获得反馈的更开放性的方向 - 既来自开发人员，又是他们可能拥有的任何EC返回渠道。 （正式地，欧共体不向其监管主题提供逐个发行的反馈。）

表明苹果与EC关于合规性非正式接触的另一个变化是PWA上的“没关系” 。欧盟iOS 17.4的Beta版本将主屏幕Web应用程序更改为在用户默认浏览器中的新选项卡中打开的书签。苹果公司之所以做出这一更改，不是因为他们想“杀死” Web应用程序1 ，而是因为他们的印象是DMA要求他们（a）在欧盟中根本没有主屏幕Web应用程序支持，或者（b）允许所有第三方渲染引擎使用其渲染引擎将PWA保存到主屏幕。 Option (c) — the status quo, WebKit-only PWA support on the Home Screen — is seemingly disallowed under the DMA, as it would constitute preferencing WebKit over third-party engines. Apple doesn't have a system in place in iOS to allow third-party rendering engines to save web apps to the Home Screen, so, alas, (a) it was — no more PWAs in the EU. The DMA is not clear about much, but it is seemingly clear that gatekeepers cannot preference their own web browser or rendering engine. Allowing PWAs — but only via WebKit — is, obviously, showing preference to WebKit. Apple's initial decision to remove PWAs in the EU sucked, but that's because the DMA sucks, not because Apple hates or fears web apps. But I think what happened is that when the EC realized the DMA was going to result in a worse PWA experience, they let Apple know that WebKit-only PWAs would not be penalized. 2

So my gut feeling is that we're seeing Apple adopt changes in response to unofficial feedback from the EC. If so, that suggests that the things Apple isn't changing — like the Core Technology Fee — are either OK with the EC, or, if not, that Apple is willing to fight for them. Or perhaps we'll be right back here with additional compliance plan changes every Tuesday for the next few weeks.

  1. If Apple wanted to kill web apps they'd have made this change worldwide in iOS 17.4, not limited to the EU. And they wouldn't have been adding new web app features to WebKit, on both iOS and especially MacOS , just in the last year. But there exists a contingent of tinfoil-hat-wearing web app zealots who think PWAs are like this close to taking over mobile app development — the dream of write-once/run-everywhere just within grasp — and it's mean old monopolistic walled-garden-defending Apple that's holding them back, because PWAs threaten the App Store . That's just nonsense. The truth is PWAs just aren't popular. Almost no normal people use them, or even know they exist. “That's because Apple is holding PWAs back by withholding features from WebKit ”, goes the conspiracy thinking. Most recently, it was mobile push notification support. Then WebKit added that . It's like desktop Linux getting popular, or Bluetooth getting reliable: always “next year”. Except with PWAs, web developers can imagine it's somehow Apple's fault, not the fact that users prefer idiomatic native apps from app stores — including on Android, which has always used Chrome's web rendering engine, and which has all the features PWA advocates want from WebKit 。 ↩︎

  2. I also suspect that Apple, eventually, will support PWAs in iOS in the EU using third-party browser engines, if possible. But it's easy to see how complicated that could be. What happens if a user installs Chrome, then uses Chrome to install a PWA using Chrome's Blink rendering engine, and then deletes Chrome from their iPhone? How does that PWA continue to function after its rendering engine has been removed from the system? It can't just automatically fall back to using WebKit because (a) the PWA might be using features only available in Chrome (that's the whole reason web developers are clamoring for third-party rendering engines); and (b) the PWA's stored data is tied to the rendering engine that created it. This is not a simple problem to solve. ↩︎︎

entry.title: ★ Apple Adjusts DMA Plan to Offer Direct Downloading of Apps From the Web (With a Big Asterisk), Custom Link-Out Screens, and Marketplaces Solely for the Distribution of a Developer's Own Apps
House Passes Bill That Requires ByteDance to Sell TikTok or Face Ban in the US
entry.content:
Cristiano Lima-Strong, Jacob Bogage, and Mariana Alfaro, reporting for The Washington Post:

The House overwhelmingly passed a measure Wednesday to force TikTok to split from its parent company or face a national ban, a lightning offensive that materialized abruptly after years of unsuccessful negotiations over the platform's fate. The legislation, approved 352 to 65 , is a sweeping bipartisan rebuke of the popular video-sharing app — and an attempt to grapple with allegations that TikTok's China-based parent, ByteDance, presents national security risks.

For years, lawmakers have been introducing proposals seeking to restrict the company's activities in the US, and finding limited momentum. But these lengthy behind-the-scenes deliberations were hastened, lawmakers said, by the Biden administration's growing support of the effort, coupled with concerns about TikTok's potential to influence US politics, whichintensified after the Oct. 7 Hamas attack on Israel.

Private briefings from national security and law enforcement officials, including a classified hearing last week, served as a “call to action” for Congress to “finally” take a stand against TikTok, said Rep. Kathy Castor (D-Fla.), a member of the House Energy and Commerce Committee. It's unclear whether these meetings with the FBI, Justice Department and Office of the Director of the National Intelligence surfaced new evidence against the company.

It seems pretty clear those briefings did surface alarming evidence. The two concerns about TikTok are that (a) the Chinese government is using it to surveil Americans; and (b) that it serves as a powerful propaganda vehicle for the PRC. It's the latter concern — propaganda — that has had me calling for a TikTok ban (or divestiture by ByteDance) for years .

Remember too: China itself bans all foreign social networks. Facebook, Instagram, Threads, Twitter/X, Pinterest — none of them are available in mainland China. It's bananas that we allow an algorithmically-driven social media app controlled by China here.

entry.title: The DMA Has Crippled Google Search in the EU
entry.content:
Oliver Bethel, legal director at Google, back in January, on changes to search results in the EU:

When you are searching for something like a hotel, or something to buy, we often show information to help you find what you need, like pictures and prices, as part of our results. Sometimes this can be as part of a result for a single business like a hotel or restaurant, or sometimes it can be a featured group of relevant results. Over the coming weeks in Europe, we will be expanding our testing of a number of changes to the search results page. We will introduce dedicated units that include a group of links to comparison sites from across the web, and query shortcuts at the top of the search page to help people refine their search, including by focusing results just on comparison sites.

entry.title: Steven Sinofsky: 'Building Under Regulation'
entry.content:
Steven Sinofsky, back on January 27 (two days after Apple announced the first draft of their DMA compliance plans):

This week Apple detailed the software changes that will appear in an upcoming release of iOS to comply with the European Union Digital Markets Act (DMA). As I read the over 60 pages of the DMA when it was passed (and in drafts before that, little of which changed in the process) my heart sank over the complexity of a regulation so poorly constructed yet so clearly aimed at specific (American) companies and products. As I read through many of the hundreds of pages of Apple documents detailing their compliance implementation my heart sank again. This time was because I so thoroughly could feel the pain and struggle product teams felt in clinging to at best or unwinding at worst the most substantial improvement in computing ever introduced — the promise behind the iPhone since its introduction. The reason the iPhone became so successful was not a fluke. Consumers and customers voted that the value proposition of the product was something they preferred, and they acted by purchasing iPhone and developers responded by building applications for iOS. The regulators have a different view of that promise, so here we are.

Sinofsky warns that his essay is long, and it is. At over 18,000 words, it's veritably booklet-length. But it's really worth reading. I read it shortly after Sinofsky published it, and have been meaning to comment upon sections at length, but I might as well just link to it. Sinofsky, having been in charge of Windows when Microsoft went through the same sort of European Commission regulatory wringer Apple is now, is in a unique position to expound upon the dynamic. His focus on Apple's “brand promise” with the iPhone, and how nearly every aspect of the DMA compliance plan breaks — or at least chips away at — that promise, is spot on.

The whole point of the DMA is the EC asserting that they know better than Apple (and Google) how phones should work.

★

entry.title: App Store WTF of the Week: DealMachine for Real Estate

[ Update, 20 March: Turns out that DealMachine was exempt from being required to use IAP, ostensibly because physical products/goods are sold as part of their subscription. But, as of this update, DealMachine is now using IAP. Original post below.]

Message from a DF reader:

I came across an app that's getting away with directly linking to a website to start a subscription instead of IAP. It's a straightforward violation of App Store rules in the US. If you look at reviews, a lot of people complain about fraudulent charges and not being able to cancel. But apparently Apple hasn't stopped them yet.

I downloaded the app and signed up; immediately after confirming your email address, you get sent to a screen in the app where you choose from account tiers to begin a free trial. The lowest tier is $100/month, the highest is $500/month. And after making your selection, you get sent to this page on DealMachine's website to pay using Stripe. (That link won't actually work, because I omitted the tracking code portion of the URL for the throwaway account I created, so here's a screenshot .) Not only are they circumventing in-app payments, they don't even offer using them as a choice.

Here's a review from their App Store Listing:

No Customer Support / Rough
Their annual plan is over a thousand dollars. I haven't used their service in months. The renewal comes around, they charge me another thousand dollars. I reach out to get a refund, all I get is a robot.

I don't think DealMachine is a scam. Stripe is as legit as it gets. But when you handle payments on your own, you handle refunds and subscription cancellations on your own too. Renewal reminders too. And if you don't send renewal reminders, customers don't get them. And if you don't feel like issuing a refund for a $1,000/year subscription that a customer wanted to cancel but didn't, you can let the customer sort it out with their credit card company. All that stuff works awesome, from the user's perspective, with Apple's App Store payment system. So DealMachine offers a taste of what our friends in the EU may be getting from marketplace apps soon.

entry.summary: Although Apple as an institution granted, revoked, and under public pressure reinstated Epic's new account, from the perspective of Apple leadership, they only revoked a new account that had been created through an automated system — not for criticism, per se, but for the same reason Epic's Fortnite developer account remains revoked and Fortnite remains unavailable on Apple platforms worldwide: for the 2020 Fortnite IAP Trojan horse stunt.
entry.content:
Three weeks ago , when Epic Games announced their approval from Apple for a new Apple developer account, under Epic's Swedish subsidiary, and their intention to use that account to create an Epic Games Store app marketplace in the EU, the assumption was that this had been approved at a high level inside Apple. It seemed pretty safe to assume that no one at Apple had forgotten who Epic is, and that was certainly how Epic presented it, starting with Tim Sweeney graciously describing it as “a good faith move by Apple amidst our cataclysmic antitrust battle”.

So the conventional wisdom as to what has occurred from then forward goes like this:

  1. Epic, seeing the opportunity offered by Apple's DMA compliance plan in the EU, petitions Apple for a new developer account to create an EU marketplace.
  2. Senior Apple executives — perhaps Phil Schiller, head of the App Store, personally — consider the petition, and despite having previously banned Epic Games's Fortnite developer account for the 2020 in-app payments Trojan horse stunt, decide to grant it.
  3. Epic announces their plans.
  4. Apple then revokes Epic's newly-granted developer account, citing other recent tweets from Sweeney in which he scathingly criticizes Apple's DMA compliance plan.
  5. Epic goes public with the correspondence from Schiller ( email to Sweeney , asking for assurances) and Apple's attorney (letter [pp. 1 and 2 ] to Epic's attorneys, officially terminating the new account, and thus, briefly, dashing Epic's plans for its own EU marketplace.
  6. Everyone, largely assuming item 2 in this list, sees this as astonishingly thin-skinned retaliation on Apple's part for public remarks criticizing Apple's plans. “Everyone” here includes EC commissioner Thierry Breton, who tweets that he is immediately opening an investigation.
  7. Under this pressure, Apple relents and reinstates Epic's newly-created account and agrees to allow the Epic Games Store marketplace to proceed.

This list is largely true, but the problem is item 2. Epic, under the assumption or hope that the DMA demanded Apple permit them to open a store, had simply gone through the enrollment form on Apple's developer website and paid the $99 annual fee. Per Sweeney , responding to a question from me tonight on Twitter/X, that was Friday, February 9, and their account was approved on the following Monday, February 12. Epic made their public announcement that they intended to create an Epic Games Store for iOS in the EU on Friday, February 16.

That announcement, seemingly, was in fact the first time Epic's plans came to the attention of Apple's leadership. Schiller's email to Sweeney was sent the following Friday, February 23, and concluded:

You have stated that allowing enrollment of Epic Games Sweden in the Developer Program is “a good faith move by Apple.” We invite you to provide us with written assurance that you are also acting in good faith, and that Epic Games Sweden will, despite your public actions and rhetoric, honor all of its commitments. In plain, unqualified terms, please tell us why we should trust Epic this time.

It doesn't make any sense for Schiller to have asked that on February 23 if any senior Apple executives had considered the implications — including Epic's history of performative non-compliance with the App Store's terms — and explicitly approved Epic's new developer account two weeks earlier 。 Florian Mueller was the first observer to note this, in a post on his new site Games Fray on March 6 , this past Wednesday:

The original grant of the developer account appeared to be a sign of a potential improvement of their relationship, but that may have been the result of an oversight as opposed to a conscious decision by Apple's executives and lawyers to give Epic a chance to prove to be a reliable app store operator in the EU. Right after the developer account was announced (February 16, 2024), Epic's Swedish subsidiary applied for a DMA consultation slot, and five days later apparently saw that the request had been turned down. Those consultations are offered by Apple to organizations interested in exercising certain rights under the DMA with a view to alternative app stores. The fact that they weren't going to talk to Epic about this was already a first negative sign.

Stephen Warwick, reporting for iMore, followed up on Florian's speculation and confirmed it :

Apple has confirmed to iMore that Epic Games Sweden entered the DLPA without any executive review on Apple's part, confirming Mueller's suspicion.

To be clear, regardless of executive review, “Apple” had approved Epic Games Sweden's developer account. But that approval was seemingly automated, or mostly automated, and only after that did Apple executives and lawyers engage Epic in any back-and-forth regarding assurances of future compliance with Apple's DMA guidelines.

So the real order of events is something more like this:

  1. Epic Games Sweden enrolls in the developer program online and gets approval after the weekend.
  2. Epic presumes, somewhat reasonably, that this means they have the go-ahead. 1 It is very Apple-like to simply grant the new account without any personal contact. Epic knows Apple is doing this through gritted teeth, because Apple itself has made clear they don't agree with any of the demands of the DMA.
  3. Epic announces their plan for an iOS games store.
  4. Now Schiller and others in Apple leadership ponder the question of what to do, and a week later Schiller emails Sweeney.
  5. Sweeney responds in the affirmative, replying to Schiller: “Epic and its subsidiaries are acting in good faith and will comply with all terms of current and future agreements with Apple, and we'll be glad to provide Apple with any specific further assurances on the topic that you'd like.”
  6. Apple considers that insufficient, thinking something to the effect of “ These guys complained incessantly about the App Store before pulling their Fortnite IAP stunt, and we perma-banned them for good reason then. Now they're complaining just as incessantly about our DMA compliance plans, so they're just as likely to pull a rule-breaking stunt again if we grant them a developer account to run a marketplace in the EU. Nothing's changed with Epic, so screw 'em, they still don't deserve to be in the developer program. ”

Ie, while Apple as an institution granted, revoked, and under public pressure reinstated Epic's new account, from the perspective of Apple leadership, they only revoked a new account that had been created through an automated system — not for criticism, per se, but for the same reason Epic's Fortnite developer account remains revoked and Fortnite remains unavailable on Apple platforms worldwide: for the 2020 Fortnite IAP Trojan horse stunt. The “colorful” tweets Schiller quoted and which Apple's attorney cited were mentioned as proof that Epic hadn't changed, not as the reason for revoking the new account.

I'm farting into the wind by writing about this somewhat subtle distinction, because the conventional wisdom isn't going to change. Almost everyone paying any attention at all to this will continue to believe, forever, that Apple executives granted Epic a new developer account and then revoked it because Tim Sweeney tweeted things Apple didn't like about their DMA plans. 2

The bottom line remains as I concluded Friday : Apple played this whole thing terribly. The automated developer program enrollment form — the one that gave Epic the impression they'd been granted express permission to proceed with building an iOS marketplace for the EU — is Apple's. The whole App Store bureaucracy is Apple's. (Or as Sweeney aptly called it tonight, “ Apple's App DMV ”.)

At the beginning of Apple attorney Mark Perry's letter terminating Epic's new developer account, he lays bare Apple's thinking:

In the past, Epic has denigrated Apple's developer terms, including the Developer Program License Agreement (DPLA) as a prelude to breaking them.

To Apple executives, it might have made sense to cite in their correspondence with Epic their ongoing denigration of Apple's developer terms, as evidence that Epic remains recalcitrant and untrustworthy. To almost everyone outside Apple Park, however — most especially (a) third-party developers who have been, for years, souring on Apple's App Store policies; and (b) EC commissioners, who are ebulliently roasting Apple as a regulatory target and feasting on the resulting publicity — it looks not like a policy of “ We're not going to reinstate Developer Program privileges to a proven rule-breaker whose stated goal was then, and remains now, to break our control over our own platform ”, but instead a retaliatory policy of “ We'll terminate the account of any developer who speaks out against us. ”

That Apple couldn't see how this would play is on them.

  1. I asked Sweeney on Twitter/X about the approval timeline , wondering whether it was measured in mere hours (or minutes, even) or days. If it had been immediately, or nearly so, wouldn't it seem likely to have been part of an automated approval for new developer accounts, not a dramatic change of stance on Apple's part regarding Epic Games post-Fortnite IAP lawsuit? Apple fought hard in court — US court, of course, which now matters — to assert its right to revoke Epic's Fortnite developer account and permanently ban Fortnite from the App Store . But if Sweeney is correct and the approval of the new account came three days after enrollment — even if over a weekend — it seems reasonable for Epic to have assumed they were cleared. Not that Apple had a change of heart, but that Apple accepted that the DMA changed the ground rules in the EU.

    Which, it is now clear, the DMA has indeed done. ↩︎

  2. Apple attorney Mark Perry's letter to Epic's attorneys informing them Apple was terminating Epic's new developer program account cited just one tweet , in which Sweeney embedded a photo of the two Steves working on an Apple II. Sweeney doesn't mention either Steve by name, but added the photo after writing:

    Apple is a few bold and visionary decisions away from being the company they once were and that they still advertise themselves to be: beloved brand to consumers, partner to developers, and overlord to none.

    The clear implication being that Apple was different — and better — under Steve Jobs. But, Jobs is the guy who, in February 2011, emailed this to Eddy Cue and Phil Schiller :

    I think this is all pretty simple — iBooks is going to be the only bookstore on iOS devices. We need to hold our heads high. One can read books bought elsewhere, just not buy/rent/subscribe from iOS without paying us, which we acknowledge is prohibitive for many things.

    So one can imagine that if you worked with Jobs personally, considered him a friend, and continue to miss him dearly, you might be a bit annoyed — to say the least — by Sweeney's insinuation that he knows how Jobs would proceed today with the App Store better than you. ↩︎︎

entry.summary: If Apple had just let Epic proceed from the start, they'd have looked magnanimous. But as it stands, Apple looks bitter, and from the EC's perspective, in need of close policing.
entry.content:
Epic Games :

Apple has told us and committed to the European Commission that they will reinstate our developer account. This sends a strong signal to developers that the European Commission will act swiftly to enforce the Digital Markets Act and hold gatekeepers accountable. We are moving forward as planned to launch the Epic Games Store and bring Fortnite back to iOS in Europe.向前！

Tim Sweeney :

The DMA went through its first major challenge with Apple banning Epic Games Sweden from competing with the App Store, and the DMA just had its first major victory. Following a swift inquiry by the European Commission, Apple notified the Commission and Epic that it would relent and restore our access to bring back Fortnite and launch Epic Games Store in Europe under the DMA law.

A big win for European rule of law, for the European Commision, and for the freedom of developers worldwide to speak up. #FreeFortnite!

This is in response to a tweet, just yesterday, from Thierry Breton of the European Commission (emojis and hashtags untouched) :

🚨Under the #DMA, there is no room for threats by gatekeepers to silence developers.

I have asked our services to look into Apple's termination of Epic's developer account as a matter of priority.

To all developers in 🇪🇺 & 🌍: now is the time to have your say on gatekeepers' compliance solutions!

(I had a version of this post almost ready to publish before I ran out of gas late last night; I seemingly can't write fast enough to keep up with Apple's EU regulatory adventure. Today's Dithering is, I think, a particularly good episode and still relevant, but its shelf life of being up-to-date on the news was about 6 hours.)

Theory A: Apple is playing grandmaster-level chess, and orchestrated this entire back-and-forth to give the EU a high-publicity win — “ Look, the DMA, just one day old, is already working, showing that we can push Apple around ” — regarding an Epic Games Store that Apple should have just let through from the start. It's a lot of publicity for a thing that I don't expect will amount to a significant concession by Apple.

Theory B: Apple is flailing erratically trying to deal with their loss of autonomy.

I vote B, because to me the real win for Apple would have been just letting Epic use their Swedish subsidiary to open an iOS games store without the back-and-forth. If Apple had gone that route, the European Commission could still have taken credit for proof of the DMA's effectiveness, and Apple would look like they were complying graciously with the law. But the way things actually played out makes clear they're complying begrudgingly, and, worse, plays into the worst assumptions about Apple's institutional arrogance and vindictiveness.

Apple seems to have been particularly wrong-footed (to borrow a sports analogy even EU citizens might get) by this Epic thing. Again, I think Apple should have let Epic open an Epic Games Store in the EU. I think Apple could have just made clear from the moment they announced their DMA compliance plans that Epic remained ineligible for a developer account because of their flagrant violation of the App Store rules four years ago. The EC might have — and I think would have — forced Apple to relent on that, but it could have been adjudicated without any implication of spite or pettiness on Apple's part.

But instead Apple played it the worst way possible: They let Epic's Swedish subsidiary open a new Apple Developer Account, and proceed far enough toward building a games store that Epic announced it , and only then revoked Epic's developer account, while almost literally justifying it not on the grounds that Epic can't be trusted because they're an egregious rule breaker, but instead because Tim Sweeney continued to voice his strident (or if you prefer, colorful ) opinions about the App Store being an illegal monopoly. Apple doesn't revoke developer licenses for criticizing Apple. But a lot of people — including the EC! — now think Apple did just that.

How was a “priority” investigation by the EC not going to happen the way Apple played this? If Apple had just let Epic proceed from the start, they'd have looked magnanimous. They even had Tim Sweeney calling it “ a good faith move ”. But as it stands, Apple looks bitter, and from the EC's perspective, in need of close policing.
